Saturday, July 25.speaker: Rhiju Das, PhD
Saturday, July 25.affiliation: Principal Investigator, Eterna; Das Lab, Stanford University
Saturday, July 25.abstract: Many things have happened in Eterna's last year. This is a chance to reflect on what we have accomplished, and where we will head next.

Saturday, July 25.speaker: Kathrin Leppek, PhD, Do Soon Kim
Saturday, July 25.affiliation: Barna Lab, Stanford University; Das Lab, Stanford University
Saturday, July 25.topic: OpenVaccine – enhancing mRNA vaccines to fight SARS-CoV2
Saturday, July 25.abstract: OpenVaccine – enhancing mRNA vaccines to fight SARS-CoV2 by integrating Eterna-derived sequences and RNA biology in the lab to come up with optimal design solutions for mRNA vaccines.

Saturday, July 25.speaker: Mia Mihailovic
Saturday, July 25.affiliation: Chemical Engineering Ph.D. Candidate, Contreras Lab, University of Texas at Austin
Saturday, July 25.abstract: RNAs are increasingly recognized as useful design platforms for rapid, post-transcriptional, targeted cellular regulation. Native RNA regulators are enabled by their intra- and inter-molecular interactions that dictate their structure and specific sites of imparted activity. In mimicry of regional-level RNA activity, we have designed a high-throughput, next generation sequencing-enabled tool for evaluating the basepairing availability of user-defined RNA regions of interest. In this talk, we will describe our application of these types of characterization tools (both cell free and intracellular) to rationally and modularly re-design RNAs for desired activity. We will further talk on preliminary efforts to expand our method-based platform to address longstanding challenges in the field, including therapeutic RNA optimization as well as recognition of long-range tertiary contacts.

Saturday, July 25.speaker: Brourd
Saturday, July 25.abstract: It is the first annual Eternacon PuzzleJam! This event will be a celebration of puzzle making in Eterna. All Eternacon participants will be given a 24 hour time period to make three puzzles with different provided prompts. Players will submit their puzzles on the Eterna site, where the favorites will be voted on to move on to a final selection on day 2. The players whose puzzles are ultimately chosen will be entitled to bragging rights and maybe even other swag (points, badges, merchandising rights)! This will be a perfect opportunity for players to show off their skills in Eterna in both solving and making puzzles. Tune in on the first day for the puzzle prompts and compete with other players for the title of puzzle making master.

Saturday, July 25.speaker: Andrew Murphy (rna-key)
Saturday, July 25.affiliation: Eterna Player; Owner, Keystone Research Solutions
Saturday, July 25.topic: The story of "A Gamer’s Guide to Eterna"
Saturday, July 25.abstract: The 84 page first edition of “A Gamer’s Guide to Eterna” came about through six years of interaction in our work internship program for local high school senior students. To support this year’s students, I gathered and organized material, wrote as if introducing a general gamer to Eterna, then illustrated and produced the electronic book. So far since May, 30 of our interns have spent 600+ hours in Eterna on 1300+ puzzles (total puzzles, not unique puzzles).

Saturday, July 25.speaker: Daniela Ruiz, Diana Varela Ajche, Ellanique Collins, Alexis Vanzandt, Chelsea Narcisse, Kristina Littlejohn
Saturday, July 25.topic: PVAMU Eterna Lab Rats Respond Positively To Eterna
Saturday, July 25.abstract:
Engaging in research over the past year at Prairie View A&M University (PVAMU) has been a most satisfying experience. Our research focused on using bioinformatics databases to characterize novel genes. Most recently we were introduced to Eterna, which uses a novel gaming technique to expose students to RNA research. Our objective was to determine the challenges, if any, that PVAMU students face when they play Eterna.

We hypothesize that the gaming aspect of Eterna will present few challenges to PVAMU undergraduate students. Ten PVAMU students were introduced to Eterna in June 2020. Students were asked to discuss their Eterna experience over the past month. Now known as the PVAMU Etrna Lab Rats, all ten students have played the puzzles on the Eterna website and found the games to be fun and informative. However, a few challenges faced were (1) students’ lack of knowledge on certain vocabulary terms needed to play puzzles and (2) were unable to play the game on their mobile devices, and encountered problems within the chat box. In conclusion, 100% of the students have enjoyed their experience playing Eterna. They have advanced onto new levels, found entertainment maneuvering bases, and have enjoyed the support amongst experienced players within the game. However, our findings demonstrated that there are still opportunities to further enhance, develop, and improve the players performance. This can be achieved by implementing resources within the game. Our hypothesis suggests that improvements need to be established throughout the program in order to maximize our team performance.

Saturday, July 25.speaker: Martin Skladany, J.D.
Saturday, July 25.abstract: Current patent and copyright theory sounds inspiring. Yet examining how both laws were created, have evolved overtime, and generate negative externalities is sobering. Radical reform is required.

Saturday, July 25.speaker: Astromon
Saturday, July 25.topic: Ribosome Challenge Round One - Analysis, Tips, and Methods
Saturday, July 25.abstract: Analysis of Round 1 of the Ribosome Challenge

Saturday, July 25.speaker: Hoglahoo
Saturday, July 25.abstract: Join in our annual challenge to solve a puzzle specifically designed for Eternacon 2020

Sunday, July 26.speaker: Francesco Cavallari
Sunday, July 26.affiliation: Founder and President, Video Games Without Borders
Sunday, July 26.topic: Flatten Island: the game supporting the fight against COVID-19
Sunday, July 26.abstract:
In the latest months, we have heard a lot about how to #FlattenTheCurve ... now it's time to prove what we have learned! Video Games Without Borders recently released Flatten Island, the game supporting the fight against #COVID19. Manage the emergency with your decisions... and with a touch of humor!

Play for FREE, DONATE if you can!
https://flattenisland.org

Sunday, July 26.speaker: Hannah Wayment-Steele
Sunday, July 26.topic: EternaFold: Learning better secondary structure prediction from Eterna data
Sunday, July 26.abstract: The diverse high-throughput structural data gathered from Eterna Cloud Labs and Riboswitch challenges has made it possible to develop the best secondary structure folding engine yet to date -- EternaFold, which is now available as another folding engine in Eterna.  We will talk about the data that enabled this to be and how we compare EternaFold to other secondary structure packages, and how Eterna players can continue to help improve secondary structure prediction.

Sunday, July 26.speaker: Hannah Wayment-Steele
Sunday, July 26.topic: The p(unp) Challenges: Computational forecasts for vaccine stabiliziation
Sunday, July 26.abstract: RNA molecules are inherently unstable, yet there is greater need than ever to develop principles to design stabilized mRNA molecules for therapeutics. Recently, we launched a lab asking Eterna players to design a variety of mRNAs minimizing "p(unp)", a measure related to how degradable the molecule is. We'll describe how Eterna players compared to standard mRNA design methods, as well as computer algorithms trying to minimize p(unp), and what the p(unp) lab predicts for future vaccine development efforts.

Sunday, July 26.speaker: Zoe Watson, Fred Ward, and Jamie H. D. Cate, PhD
Sunday, July 26.topic: Structures of wild type and engineered ribosomes
Sunday, July 26.abstract: Cryogenic electron microscopy (cryo-EM) is a powerful technique for understanding the structural biology of the ribosome, suitable for the two-pronged goal of teasing out alternative conformational states and achieving high resolution. In this talk we will present cryo-EM structures of a mutant engineered ribosome, called P7A7, and the wild type E. coli ribosome. P7A7 carries 12 mutations in the active site, which have previously been shown to allow for incorporation of beta-amino acids into a protein chain in the cell. However, the structure shows these mutations act to severely disrupt the folding and assembly of the large subunit in vitro. This result suggests that new approaches will be needed to experiment with ribosomal function in a way that is less detrimental to its proper assembly. In part 2 of this talk, our recent high resolution structure of the wild type ribosome is presented to highlight what we can learn at 2 Å resolution.

Sunday, July 26.speaker: Amy Barish (amybarish)
Sunday, July 26.abstract: The results of the OpenVaccine Lightning Round will be presented and discussed.  This was the first lab in Eterna's attempt to stabilize mRNA and eventually optimize a vaccine for Covid-19.  Find out what we have learned so you can apply to future labs!

Sunday, July 26.speaker: Jonathan Romano (LFP6)
Sunday, July 26.topic: Eterna Development Year In Review: Refresh and Beyond
Sunday, July 26.abstract: Over the past year there have been many exciting developments in the Eterna platform from both a user-facing and technical perspective. Let's take a moment to celebrate and appreciate these advancements, and look into the future to what Eterna can become.

Sunday, July 26.speaker: Antje Krüger, PhD
Sunday, July 26.topic: Discovering Stabilized Ribosomes - Towards New Machines for Making Smart Therapeutics and Materials
Sunday, July 26.abstract:
About a year ago we started the ribosome challenge, which included the biggest and most complicated puzzles ever deployed on Eterna. We were aiming high, but we were confident that the enthusiasm and creativity of the Eterna community would make it solvable. The stunning results of the challenge speak for themselves. These are exciting times for us scientists and hopefully for you players, too.

In this talk, I will discuss the motivation and goal of the challenge, provide some information about assembly and functionality of the ribosome, illustrate how I test players’ designs in lab, and present the latest round 2 results.

Sunday, July 26.speaker: Ronald Lorenzo, PhD
Sunday, July 26.topic: Who becomes an Eterna player and why? A sociological framework for understanding citizen science motivation in an online RNA game
Sunday, July 26.abstract: In The Lonely Crowd (1950) sociologist David Riesman explores the three various types of social character present in society, their emotional motivations, and their interactions with media of communication.  Different from personality, social character refers to the social organization of preferences and goals within individuals, as well as their emotional drives.  Based on Riesman’s theoretical framework, I extend his insights to interpret participation in online citizen science video games generally and Eterna specifically.  I elaborate on two different forms of social character found within contemporary society: inner-directed character types and other-directed character types.  The Inner-directed type is drawn to activities as temporary withdrawals from the world, where the individual can find solitude.  Inner-directed types are motivated by goals based on permanent values, and they are more likely to engage in altruistic behavior such as engaging in citizen science.  Other-directed types are motivated by social cues taken from their peers, and when they retreat into video games, it is as an attempted escape from the pervasive anxiety they experience in contemporary society.  Other-directed types do not have goals based on permanent values, and they are less likely to commit to citizen science out of altruistic notions.  Based on the social character profiles of potential citizen scientists, I extend Riesman’s framework to offer suggestions for recruiting and retaining participants from the two types.

Sunday, July 26.speaker: Astromon
Sunday, July 26.abstract: Introduction and overview of the Eterna Players Alliance

Players will submit their puzzles on the Eterna site, where the favorites will be voted on to move on to a final selection on day 2. The players whose puzzles are ultimately chosen will be entitled to bragging rights and maybe even other swag (points, badges, merchandising rights)!
